message.content: This question tests knowledge about the different ways living things can sense their surroundings. Feeling refers to the sense of touch, which allows living things to perceive their environment through contact. Options (A), (B), and (D) are all incorrect because they refer to other senses: sight, smell, and taste, respectively.

This question requires knowledge about the different ways living things can sense their environment. Feeling refers to the sense of touch or contact. Option (A) is incorrect because sight refers to the sense of vision, not touch. Option (B) is incorrect because smell refers to the sense of olfaction, not touch. Option (D) is incorrect because taste refers to the sense of gustation, not touch.

This question requires knowledge about the different senses by which living things can perceive their environment. Feeling refers to the sense of touch or contact. Option (A) is incorrect because sight refers to the sense of vision, not feeling. Option (B) is incorrect because smell refers to the sense of olfaction, not feeling. Option (D) is incorrect because taste refers to the sense of gustation, not feeling.

This question requires knowledge about the different senses that living things use to perceive their surroundings. Option (A) is incorrect because sight refers specifically to the sense of vision. Option (B) is incorrect because smell refers specifically to the sense of olfaction. Option (D) is incorrect because taste refers specifically to the sense of gustation. The correct answer is (C) contact, which refers to the sense of touch. Feeling is the ability to perceive physical stimuli through touch, such as pressure, heat, and texture.
